title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing number of workers as 144 and/or does not explain that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.
The response identifies the profit-maximizing number of workers as 144 and explains that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the wage the firm will pay as $104 and/or does not explain that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

The response identifies the wage the firm will pay as $104 and explains that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that there will be a shortage at a wage of $86, does not calculate the shortage as 144 veterinarians, and/or does not show the work.

Shortage=Quantity Demanded−Quantity Supplied=252−108=144 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6ABE@

The response states that there will be a shortage at a wage of $86, calculates the shortage as 144 veterinarians, and shows the work.

Shortage=Quantity Demanded−Quantity Supplied=252−108=144 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6ABE@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity of services provided will decrease and/or does not explain that as each worker’s extra output (marginal product) decreases, the firm’s MRP decreases, decreasing the quantity of labor hired as well as the quantity of output produced by the firm.

The response states that the quantity of services provided will decrease and explains that as each worker’s extra output (marginal product) decreases, the firm’s MRP decreases, decreasing the quantity of labor hired as well as the quantity of output produced by the firm.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that the firm should rent less capital and/or does not explain that the ratio of the marginal product of labor to the wage (0.5) is greater than the ratio of the marginal product of capital to the rental price of capital (0.25), or the firm can get more output for their money by hiring more workers and renting less capital, or

M P Labor P Labor > M P Capital P Capital MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5704@

50 100 > 10 40 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4155@

0.5>0.25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F36@

The response states that the firm should rent less capital and explains that the ratio of the marginal product of labor to the wage (0.5) is greater than the ratio of the marginal product of capital to the rental price of capital (0.25), or the firm can get more output for their money by hiring more workers and renting less capital, or

M P Labor P Labor > M P Capital P Capital MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5704@

50 100 > 10 40 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4155@

0.5>0.25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F36@
